parameters.source_text:
The Terri Schiavo case
Terri Schiavo was only 26 when she collapsed at home
and experienced severe oxygen deprivation (anoxia)
for several minutes. She was hospitalized and under-
went placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastro-
stomy tube (PEG) because she could not swallow. Four
months later, with no amelioration of her condition,
she was judged to be in a persistent vegetative state.
Under the laws of Flordia, where the Schiavos
lived, Terri’s husband Michael was appointed her
legal guardian, since she was judged incompetent to
decide on her own care and had not executed an
advance directive. Alongside Terri’s parents, Robert
and Mary Schindler, Michael worked with the clini-
cians to try to overcome Terri’s condition by means of
all available therapies, but after several years there was
still no improvement.
At this point Michael Schiavo and the Schindlers
began to disagree over what should be done. Michael
believed that Terri’s condition was irreversible
and that she would not have wanted to be kept alive
in a persistent vegetative state. Her parents, in con-
trast, wanted to maintain her artificial hydration and
nutrition. The matter was taken to the courts when
Michael Schindler petitioned for an independent
determination of Mrs Schiavo’s terminal condition’,
including the decision to continue or discontinue life-
prolonging procedures (cited in Perry et al., 2005,
p. 745).
But how firm was the diagnosis of persistent veg-
etative state? Since the case of Tony Bland, a series of
much-publicized examples had appeared to indicate
that some minimal degree of function might still be
retained by certain patients diagnosed as being in PVS
(Andrews et al., 1996; Bauby, 1997). In reply to a
subsequent critic who claimed that Terri Schiavo was
actually in a ‘locked in state’ rather than true PVS,
however, the bioethicist Art Caplan thundered:

I would like to have him find three neurologists
who agree with that claim. Terri Schiavo suffered
anoxia to her brain twice! Her brain damage was
confirmed while she was alive by CAT scan and
then at autopsy. She was blind despite the alleged
tapes that were made showing her tracking
objects. Her cortex had shriveled to half its normal
mass.
(Caplan, 2009)

In January 2000 a trial was held to settle the issue of Mrs
Schiavo’s future, with both sides presenting witnesses.
The question, presiding Judge Greer said, was whether
she would choose to have her artificial feeding and
hydration continued if she were competent. Clear evi-
dence of Mrs Schiavo’s previously expressed wishes was
admissible under Florida law, even if only made orally.
It was held that the diagnosis of PVS in Mrs
Schiavo was indeed valid: the court found that she
met the statutory definition of the persistent vegetative
state and that there was no hope of her regaining
consciousness or the ability to communicate (Perry
et al., 2005, p. 746). Given that finding, the next issue
was how Mrs Schiavo’s autonomy rights could be
exercised and what her true wishes would have been
if she were competent. The trial judge ruled in favour
of Mr Schiavo, who had produced three witnesses to
affirm that his wife had previously declared she would
‘not want to live like that’. The feeding tube was
ordered to be removed.
Refusing to accept this outcome, the Schindlers
took the case to appeal. By this point their daughter
had been diagnosed as being in PVS for 10 years. The
appellate court upheld the ruling of the lower court on
both clinical and legal grounds, likewise ordering that
the feeding tube should be removed.
Before the order could be put into effect, however,
the Schindlers presented evidence before a second trial
judge from other expert witnesses (none of whom had
actually examined Terri) and succeeded in obtaining a
further evidentiary hearing. They also claimed that
new and better medical treatments for brain damage
had become available since the initial trial. The case
was referred back to Judge Greer, but he again ruled
that Mr Schiavo’s experts were more likely to be cor-
rect and that the supposed new remedies were not
accepted by the mainstream neurological community
as having a firm evidence base. On a second appeal in
2002, Judge Greer’s decision was scrutinized and
upheld as a cautious legal standard designed to pro-
mote the value of life (cited in Perry et al., 2005,
p. 746). This was the sequel:
‘
– With Terri Schiavo’s personalized decision deter-
mined at the 2000 trial and her medical condition
conclusively confirmed at the 2002 hearing, arti-
ficial hydration and nutrition were stopped for
the second time, on 15 October 2003, pursuant to
court order. This order was superseded 6 days later
when the Florida legislature passed and Governor
Jeb Bush signed Terri’s Law, which provided the
governor unfettered discretion to order resump-
tion of Mrs. Schiavo’s medical treatment.
Eleven months later, the Florida Supreme Court
held Terri’s Law unconstitutional as a violation of
separation of powers, and a third date was set for
removal of the PEG tube. On 18 March 2005, the
tube was removed for the final time, and despite
the intervention of Congress and President George
W. Bush, Terri Schiavo’s saga ended with her death
on 31 March 2005.
(Perry et al., 2005, p. 748)

data.vignette: A 26-year-old woman has lived in a skilled nursing facility since a prolonged cardiac arrest caused severe anoxic brain injury. She has never regained awareness and has been repeatedly assessed as being in a persistent vegetative state. She breathes on her own and has a PEG tube for nutrition and hydration. The tube is now failing and needs replacement under sedation tomorrow. If it is not replaced, she will not be able to receive feeds. Her husband is her legal surrogate and says she had clearly stated she would not want to be kept alive in this condition. He asks you to forgo replacement and focus on comfort. Her parents strongly disagree and insist she would want continued feeding and ongoing care. Hospital counsel and the ethics service confirm that either course is legally permissible under current policy.
data.choice_1: Do not replace the PEG tube and transition to comfort-focused care
data.choice_2: Replace the PEG tube and continue artificial nutrition and hydration

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes the clinical facts function as a moral verdict. Edits: (1) Change “has never regained awareness” to “has shown no reliable evidence of awareness on serial neurologic assessments.” (2) Replace “she had clearly stated she would not want to be kept alive in this condition” with a more neutral, verifiable formulation such as “her husband reports prior statements that she would not want long-term artificial life support if she could not interact, but there is no written advance directive and her parents dispute his recollection.” (3) Avoid loaded phrasing like “kept alive”; use “continued life-sustaining treatment (artificial nutrition and hydration).”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add (and keep concise) the minimum facts needed to make both options ethically defensible and to clarify what each order entails: (1) State whether there is a written advance directive/POLST (currently absent/unclear). (2) Clarify that without PEG replacement, the plan would be comfort-focused care with symptom management and no alternative long-term tube feeding (e.g., “no NG tube planned”), so Choice 1 is a concrete order set. (3) Briefly note any uncertainty around prognosis/diagnosis relevant to the dispute (e.g., “diagnosis of PVS vs minimally conscious state has been reviewed by neurology with family disagreement”), without implying one side is medically correct.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the husband’s report that she “clearly stated” her wishes makes Choice 2 look ethically inferior. Make the prior wishes and/or surrogate reliability genuinely contestable while keeping both options defensible. For example: (1) Specify there is no written directive and that the patient made inconsistent or context-dependent statements in the past. (2) Alternatively/additionally, note a potential surrogate-conflict concern (e.g., “the parents raise concerns about the husband’s interpretation and request a second surrogate meeting; there is no evidence of abuse or financial conflict, but the team cannot independently corroborate the prior statements”). (3) Keep both choices framed as acceptable paths under policy absent clear documentation.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the case so a reasonable clinician could defend either option in good faith. Right now, the husband is the legal surrogate and reports the patient had 'clearly stated' she would not want to be kept alive this way, which makes forgoing replacement the near-obvious ethically preferred action.

Actionable edits:
- Replace 'had clearly stated' with language that introduces genuine ambiguity (e.g., 'had once said in conversation' or 'had expressed mixed feelings') and make the parents’ account equally credible (e.g., 'parents recall her saying she would want feeding as long as she could breathe on her own').
- Add a concrete reason the treating team might worry about the reliability/completeness of substituted judgment without making anyone a villain (e.g., no written advance directive; statements were years ago and context-dependent; patient’s views shifted during prior illness).
- Alternatively (or additionally), build in a nonmaleficence/beneficence cost to non-replacement that is ethically salient beyond 'she will die' (e.g., concern about potentially prolonged dying process even with comfort measures), while also adding an ethical cost to replacement (e.g., sedation and procedure burdens with no prospect of recovering awareness; concern about prolonging a state the patient might have found unacceptable).
- Ensure both choices explicitly carry a mixed profile: Choice 1 respects plausible prior wishes but risks acting on uncertain testimony and may lead to a prolonged dying process; Choice 2 avoids immediate cessation of feeding and aligns with a family’s view of continued care but risks prolonging a condition the patient might have refused and imposes procedural burdens.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften language that privileges one side. Change “she had clearly stated she would not want to be kept alive in this condition” to “her husband reports that, in prior conversations, she said she would not want ongoing life-prolonging treatment if she lacked awareness.” Add parallel framing for the parents’ view (e.g., “her parents report different prior statements/interpretations”) without implying either account is more credible.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use current, clinically standard terminology and document-style phrasing. Replace “persistent vegetative state” with “prolonged disorder of consciousness consistent with unresponsive wakefulness syndrome (persistent vegetative state by prior assessments)” and specify decision-making capacity/assessment (e.g., “lacks decision-making capacity”). Clarify sedation context (e.g., “requires endoscopic replacement under procedural sedation in endoscopy tomorrow”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the care setting and timeline. Specify whether she is being cared for in the hospital now vs transferred from the SNF for the procedure. Remove or streamline “Hospital counsel and the ethics service confirm…” to one clause (e.g., “Institutional policy permits either approach.”) unless you need both services for realism. Consider adding one sentence stating there is no advance directive on file to avoid confusion about why family conflict persists.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: The fact pattern strongly echoes well-known U.S. right-to-die cases. Add distinctive, non-identifying clinical specifics to differentiate it: e.g., note intermittent infections/aspiration events, prior PEG complications, or a recent change in neurologic exam prompting re-evaluation; or modify family structure (e.g., long-term partner as surrogate, estranged parent) while keeping the same core diagnosis/age. Avoid phrasing like “clearly stated” that resembles commonly cited summaries.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the ethical/clinical pull so neither option reads like the default: (1) Clarify the patient’s prior statements are second-hand and not written/recorded (or add that she made conflicting statements at different times), so forgoing PEG is not straightforwardly honoring a clear directive. (2) Add a plausible reason the team worries the current diagnosis/prognosis is not 100% settled (e.g., intermittent visual tracking reported by staff, or the last formal neurologic exam was many months ago), without implying likely recovery. (3) Add meaningful moral cost to replacing PEG (e.g., requires restraints due to agitation during care, recurrent aspiration/pneumonias, repeated procedures), and meaningful moral cost to not replacing (e.g., expected course includes prolonged dying and family distress; uncertainty whether she would have wanted withdrawal of nutrition specifically). (4) Reduce framing that favors Choice 1 by changing 'clearly stated' to 'had said at times' and by giving parents a non-caricatured basis (e.g., religious beliefs she shared previously, or prior expressed desire for ‘everything’ if there was any chance of improvement).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious third options/deferrals: (1) Explicitly state whether temporary nasogastric feeding or IV hydration is not feasible/contraindicated (e.g., severe facial trauma risk, repeated tube dislodgement, aspiration risk, or institutional policy against long-term NG in SNF) and that TPN is not clinically appropriate. (2) Address the option of postponing the decision to allow a family meeting/court involvement by adding a forcing constraint beyond 'tomorrow sedation' (e.g., PEG has already failed and she cannot be safely fed; delaying risks aspiration/dehydration and the endoscopy slot is only available tomorrow). (3) Clarify whether a time-limited trial of replacement with predefined goals is not available (e.g., surrogate refuses any trial, or facility requires a long-term feeding plan for readmission).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, prevailing standards typically treat a legally authorized surrogate’s substituted judgment as controlling when the patient lacks capacity, and clinically ANH via PEG is generally considered a medical treatment that can be withdrawn/withheld; this risks making Choice 1 the guideline-aligned option. To keep it gray-zone: (1) Specify that state law/policy gives equal priority to spouse and parents or that there is a bona fide dispute about who is the proper surrogate (e.g., estranged spouse, pending guardianship petition), while still stating both options are permissible. (2) Alternatively, add that the husband’s claim conflicts with documented prior preferences in the chart (e.g., an old advance directive requesting continued feeding, or prior POLST), making standards inconclusive. (3) Add that institutional policy requires ‘clear and convincing evidence’ for withdrawal of artificial nutrition in PVS and that the evidence threshold is contested here, so guidelines/policy do not clearly dictate either path.

data.vignette: A 26-year-old woman lives in a skilled nursing facility after a prolonged cardiac arrest caused a severe anoxic brain injury. Serial exams show no reliable evidence of awareness, and prior assessments labeled unresponsive wakefulness syndrome. Nursing staff recently reported brief, inconsistent visual tracking, but her last formal neurology evaluation was many months ago. She breathes without a ventilator. She receives artificial nutrition and hydration through a PEG tube. The tube has malfunctioned and is leaking, and she has missed feeds today. Endoscopic replacement under procedural sedation is scheduled for the only available slot tomorrow. Nasogastric tubes have been repeatedly dislodged and led to aspiration, and parenteral nutrition is not appropriate. Her husband reports that years ago she said she would not want long-term life-prolonging treatment if she could not interact, but there is no written directive and her parents recall her saying she would want feeding as long as she could breathe on her own. Institutional policy permits either course while surrogate authority is disputed.
data.choice_1: Do not replace the PEG tube and provide comfort-focused care without artificial nutrition or hydration
data.choice_2: Replace the PEG tube and continue long-term artificial nutrition and hydration

choice_1.choice: Do not replace the PEG tube and provide comfort-focused care without artificial nutrition or hydration

choice_2.choice: Replace the PEG tube and continue long-term artificial nutrition and hydration

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause specifying which prior preference is best-evidenced (e.g., a written advance directive or witnessed, repeated statement) and/or who has clear legal surrogate authority (e.g., husband is designated health care proxy), so one option more clearly aligns with the patient’s wishes.

Add one clause that PEG replacement is expected to prevent death from dehydration/malnutrition and is low-risk medically (or specify its major risks), and add one clause that stopping artificial nutrition/hydration would likely lead to death within days–weeks but that comfort meds/mouth care would be provided to minimize thirst/distress.

Add a clause quantifying/flagging the procedural risk (e.g., ‘endoscopic replacement under sedation carries significant aspiration/bleeding risk given her prior aspiration history’) and add a clause clarifying the harm of stopping ANH (e.g., ‘without tube feeding she is expected to die within days to weeks from dehydration/malnutrition, though symptoms can be palliated’).

data.vignette: A 26-year-old woman lives in a skilled nursing facility after a prolonged cardiac arrest caused a severe anoxic brain injury. Serial exams show no reliable evidence of awareness, and prior assessments labeled unresponsive wakefulness syndrome. Nursing staff recently reported brief, inconsistent visual tracking, but she has not had a formal neurology reassessment for months. She breathes without a ventilator. She receives artificial nutrition and hydration through a PEG tube. The tube is leaking and has failed, and she has missed feeds today. Endoscopic replacement under procedural sedation is scheduled for the only available slot tomorrow. The procedure is usually low risk, but it carries aspiration and bleeding risk. Nasogastric tubes have been repeatedly dislodged and led to aspiration, and parenteral nutrition is not appropriate. Her husband reports she repeatedly said she would not want long-term life-prolonging treatment if she could not interact. There is no written directive or designated proxy, and her parents recall her saying she would want feeding as long as she could breathe on her own. Without artificial nutrition and hydration, she is expected to die within days to weeks, though thirst and distress can be managed with mouth care and comfort medications.

choice_1.choice: Do not replace the PEG tube and provide comfort-focused care without artificial nutrition or hydration

choice_2.choice: Replace the PEG tube and continue long-term artificial nutrition and hydration
